page.title: 08CUSTOMS & EXCISE - COWES
page.content: Smuggling was well organized 150 years ago,but there is little evidence of it today.Drugs,drinks and cigarettes are the usual things to be smuggled.The main job of the{Customs(Preventive) {Officer}in Cowes is to prevent animals being imported.He can board,arrest, search and rummage in all sorts of places.He has his own boat,but his work is mostly done in his office. Boats returning from abroad must fly a yellow Q flag and contact H.M.Customs, Southampton.They usually come from France,Germany or Ireland.There are 6 or 7 Customs Officers in the Summer and 4 or 5 in the Winter.They deal mainly with pleasure craft.Cargo boats enter Cowes in the ratio of 1 Cargo boat to 60 pleasure craft.1300 yachts were handled in the first five months of 1985.
